This is the kind of film one watches in gape-jawed, horrified silence, and yet continues to watch, mesmerized, as if watching a horror flick. For four-plus hours it presents gruesome execution by the Koreans of countless captured Japanese soldiers; and one scene shows Koreans soldiers slowly disemboweling another Korean group suspected of spying on their comrades. One can imagine why director Shin Sang-ok elected to portray these barbarities as they reflect Japanese atrocities during WWII.

River Queen attempts to pack a complicated, sweeping, historical narrative into just under two hours. There are some breathtaking battle scenes and the Wanganui scenery is beautiful, well suited to this hybrid England/Australian/French/New Zealand production. But after attempting to tell the life of riverboat owner Ada‘s family and the turbulent Finn River area over two bloody wars (Maori Wars and World War I), no holes are left unexplored or water unfilled.

The Bone Snatcher is about a group miners who go on a search for a missing crew of miners in the Namib Desert. When the find them, they do not realize that what was going on with them is solely related to an unseen pre-historic danger, be it hostile paleo aquatic creatures or aliens under the sea.

What is left of Planet Earth is populated by a few poor and starving rag-tag survivors. They must eat bugs and insects, or whatever they can find. The wealthy fliers have long since left Planet Earth, for adventures across the Universe in their space ships.

Michael Dudikoff stars as Joe Armstrong a martial artist who fights ninjas who are stealing weapons from the U.S Army, in this entertaining yet admittedly brainless action film. In Canada stopping what seems to be an organized criminal outfit might seem simple enough ; but once you've seen Michael reject flying bullets and avoid being hacked apart by ninjas with swords ,you should have your expectations lowered accordingly.
